Name: Threat Actors
Description: Any person, group, or entity responsible for an event that affects security. Also called a malicious actor.

Name: Attributes of Threat Actors
Description: Internal vs. External, level of sophistication, available funding, motivation, and intent determine threat potential.

Name: Common Motivations
Description: Financial gain, data theft/exfiltration, espionage, service disruption, blackmail, ideological or ethical causes, revenge, chaos, or warfare.

Name: Nation-State Threat Actors
Description: Government-linked and highly funded. Often operate as Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) groups with maximum sophistication and stealth.

Name: Unskilled Attackers (Script Kiddies)
Description: Use pre-made tools or scripts with little understanding. Motivated by curiosity or reputation. Can be internal or external.

Name: Hacktivists
Description: Attackers driven by social, political, or ideological causes. Skill and funding vary; often rely on public exploits.

Name: Insider Threats
Description: Originates from within the organization. Motivations include revenge, profit, or coercion. Dangerous due to legitimate access.

Name: Organized Crime
Description: Professional, well-structured groups focused on financial gain. Use ransomware, fraud, and identity theft with high sophistication.

Name: Shadow IT
Description: Unauthorized systems, software, or cloud services deployed by employees. Not malicious but introduces significant risk.

Name: Threat Vectors (Attack Vectors)
Description: Methods attackers use to gain access. Includes message, file, media, voice, removable media, software, and network vectors.

Name: Message-Based Vectors
Description: Email, SMS, or instant messages delivering phishing, malware, or scams.

Name: Phishing and Variants
Description: Phishing: deceptive messages with malicious links. BEC: impersonates executives. Vishing: voice calls. Smishing: SMS phishing.

Name: Image-Based Attack Vectors
Description: Malicious code hidden inside image formats like SVG via XML-based scripting.

Name: File-Based Attack Vectors
Description: Malware hidden in PDFs, Office macros, or ZIP archives that execute upon opening or enabling scripts.

Name: Voice Call Vectors
Description: Robocalls, war dialing, or call tampering targeting VoIP or phone systems.

Name: Removable Media Vectors
Description: USB drives used to infect air-gapped systems, impersonate keyboards, or exfiltrate data.

Name: Vulnerable Software Vectors
Description: Unpatched or unsupported client/server applications become high-risk entry points.

Name: Unsecured Network Vectors
Description: Weak Wi-Fi protocols, rogue APs, open ports, or default credentials increase exposure.

Name: Supply Chain Attacks
Description: Compromise occurs at vendor or provider level before deployment to the target organization.

Name: Social Engineering Tactics
Description: Psychological manipulation using impersonation, elicitation, or identity fraud to extract information or access.

Name: Watering Hole Attacks
Description: Compromising a trusted website frequently visited by a target group to deliver malware passively.

Name: Misinformation and Disinformation
Description: Spreading false or misleading content to manipulate public opinion or behavior, often amplified through social media.

Name: Malware Basics
Description: Malicious software executes in memory or injects code into legitimate processes to evade detection.

Name: Memory Injection / DLL Injection
Description: Inserts malicious code into running processes to inherit permissions and maintain stealth.

Name: Buffer Overflow
Description: Writing data beyond allocated memory to execute attacker-controlled code; may crash systems if unhandled.

Name: Race Condition (TOCTOU)
Description: Time-of-check-to-time-of-use flaw that allows attackers to modify data between validation and execution.

Name: Software Updates and Patching
Description: Always install updates from trusted sources, validate signatures, and maintain backups.

Name: Code Injection Attacks
Description: SQL Injection modifies database queries; XSS injects scripts into web pages viewed by users.

Name: Hardware and Firmware Risks
Description: IoT and EOL/EOSL devices lack patches; isolate legacy hardware or use compensating controls.

Name: Virtualization Security
Description: Risks include VM escape and privilege escalation; mitigation through patching and isolation.

Name: Denial of Service (DoS / DDoS)
Description: Overwhelm services to cause downtime or distraction; DDoS uses distributed botnets and amplification methods.

Name: DNS Attacks
Description: Poisoning, spoofing, or hijacking DNS entries to redirect users to malicious destinations.

Name: Wireless Attacks
Description: Deauthentication and RF jamming disrupt connectivity; mitigated with 802.11w and signal monitoring.

Name: On-Path (Man-in-the-Middle) Attacks
Description: Intercept and alter communications using ARP poisoning, browser injection, or session hijacking.

Name: Indicators of Compromise (IOC)
Description: Unusual network activity, abnormal logins, missing logs, data leaks, or impossible travel events.

Name: System Hardening and Defense
Description: Apply least privilege, patch management, encryption, SIEM logging, and secure decommissioning.
